The Hatter reveals that Time is a person, implying that Alice has never met him. Alice learns that beating time is futile and that the Hatter suggests manipulating Time to adjust the clock.

The Queen interrupts the Hatter's singing, demanding his head, and Alice is shocked by her savagery. The Hatter explains the March Hare's uncooperativeness and the perpetual state of tea time, which leads to clutter. Alice is asked to tell a story, and the Dormouse tells a tale about three sisters living at the bottom of a well, surviving on treacle.

The conversation becomes even more confusing, with the group learning to draw objects starting with the letter M and the Dormouse rambling about words starting with M. Alice's frustration escalates, causing her to storm off, but the others remain oblivious. She then spots a door in a tree and enters it, finding herself back in the long hall. She uses the little golden key to unlock the door to the garden, eats a growth-enhancing mushroom, and proceeds through the passage, ultimately arriving in a stunning garden filled with flowers and fountains.

chapters.title: CHAPTER VIII.

paragraphs.original: The Queen’s Croquet-Ground   A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, “Look out now, Five! Don’t go splashing paint over me like that!”
paragraphs.summary: Near the garden entrance, a large rose-tree with white roses stood, where three gardeners were painting the roses red. Alice observed this peculiar scene, drawing closer to watch, just as one of the gardeners cautioned another, "Five, look out, don't splash paint over me!"

paragraphs.original: “I couldn’t help it,” said Five, in a sulky tone; “Seven jogged my elbow.”  On which Seven looked up and said, “That’s right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!”  “_You’d_ better not talk!” said Five. “I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!”
paragraphs.summary: Five blamed Seven for bumping his elbow, but Seven retorted that Five always shifted the blame to others, and Five threatened him after Seven mentioned that the Queen had said he deserved to be beheaded.

paragraphs.original: “What for?” said the one who had spoken first.  “That’s none of _your_ business, Two!” said Seven.  “Yes, it _is_ his business!” said Five, “and I’ll tell him—it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.”
paragraphs.summary: Seven tells Two that it's none of his business, but Five intervenes, stating that it is indeed Two's business and reveals that the reason was Two's mistake in bringing tulip-roots instead of onions for the cook.

paragraphs.original: Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun “Well, of all the unjust things—” when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.  “Would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, “why you are painting those roses?”  Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low voice, “Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a _red_ rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know. So you see, Miss, we’re doing our best, afore she comes, to—” At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out “The Queen! The Queen!” and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.
paragraphs.summary: Seven stopped mid-sentence, and he and the other gardeners bowed to Alice, who asked why they were painting roses. Two explained that they were supposed to paint a red rose tree, but had mistakenly used a white one, and if the Queen found out, they would be beheaded. Just as Two finished speaking, Five shouted "The Queen!" and the gardeners fell to the ground, followed by the sound of many footsteps approaching.

paragraphs.original: First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.  Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions; “and besides, what would be the use of a procession,” thought she, “if people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn’t see it?” So she stood still where she was, and waited.  When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?” She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
paragraphs.summary: A procession of soldiers, courtiers, royal children, and guests, including the White Rabbit and the Knave of Hearts, marched by Alice. The procession was led by the King and Queen of Hearts, who stopped and looked at Alice when they reached her. The Queen demanded to know who Alice was, but the Knave of Hearts merely bowed and smiled in response.

pages.page_summary: Alice observes gardeners painting a white rose tree red near the garden entrance, with Five accusing Seven of bumping into him. The gardeners bow to Alice, revealing they're painting the wrong tree and will be beheaded if the Queen finds out. A procession of the King, Queen, and various courtiers and guests, including the White Rabbit and Knave of Hearts, approaches, with the Queen demanding to know Alice's identity.

paragraphs.original: “Idiot!” said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, “What’s your name, child?”  “My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,” said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, “Why, they’re only a pack of cards, after all. I needn’t be afraid of them!”  “And who are _these?_” said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen, frustrated, demands to know Alice's name, which Alice responds to with politeness, but also thinks to herself that the Queen and her court are just a pack of cards, making her feel less intimidated. The Queen then asks about the three figures lying around the rose tree, but is unsure if they are gardeners, soldiers, courtiers, or her own children due to their identical backs.

paragraphs.original: “How should _I_ know?” said Alice, surprised at her own courage. “It’s no business of _mine_.”  The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—”  “Nonsense!” said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
paragraphs.summary: Alice responds to the Queen's fury with unexpected courage, saying she doesn't know what the Queen is talking about and it's not her business. The Queen's anger escalates, but Alice interrupts her, loudly declaring "Nonsense!" and silencing the Queen.

paragraphs.original: The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said “Consider, my dear: she is only a child!”  The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave “Turn them over!”  The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
paragraphs.summary: The King cautions the Queen about the child's involvement, but she turns away, ordering the Knave to flip over the cards, which he does with care, using one foot.

paragraphs.original: “Get up!” said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.  “Leave off that!” screamed the Queen. “You make me giddy.” And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, “What _have_ you been doing here?”  “May it please your Majesty,” said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, “we were trying—”
paragraphs.summary: The Queen shouted at the three gardeners to stand up and stop bowing, as it was making her dizzy. She then turned to the rose-tree and demanded to know what the gardeners had been doing there, prompting Two to humbly explain their actions.

paragraphs.original: “_I_ see!” said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses. “Off with their heads!” and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.  “You shan’t be beheaded!” said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.  “Are their heads off?” shouted the Queen.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen, having examined the roses, orders the execution of the gardeners, but Alice intervenes, hiding them in a nearby flower-pot. The soldiers search for them, then depart, and the Queen inquires if their heads have been removed.

pages.page_summary: The Queen demands to know Alice's name, but Alice thinks to herself that the Queen and her court are just a pack of cards, making her less intimidated. The Queen asks about three figures near the rose tree, but can't identify them. Alice responds to the Queen's fury with unexpected courage, declaring "Nonsense!" and silencing her. The Queen orders the Knave to flip over the cards, and then demands the gardeners stand up and explain their actions. After examining the roses, the Queen orders the gardeners' execution, but Alice intervenes, hiding them in a flower-pot.

paragraphs.original: “Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!” the soldiers shouted in reply.  “That’s right!” shouted the Queen. “Can you play croquet?”  The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
paragraphs.summary: Soldiers reply to the Queen's question about the missing heads, shouting "Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!" The Queen confirms this, then asks Alice if she can play croquet, prompting the soldiers to fall silent and look at her.

paragraphs.original: “Yes!” shouted Alice.  “Come on, then!” roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.  “It’s—it’s a very fine day!” said a timid voice at her side. She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
paragraphs.summary: Alice enthusiastically joins the procession, responding to the Queen's call, while the White Rabbit walks beside her, nervously glancing at her face and commenting on the fine day.

paragraphs.original: “Very,” said Alice: “—where’s the Duchess?”  “Hush! Hush!” said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered “She’s under sentence of execution.”  “What for?” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice asks about the Duchess's whereabouts, and the Rabbit hastily whispers that she's under sentence of execution, prompting Alice to ask what she's been sentenced for.

paragraphs.original: “Did you say ‘What a pity!’?” the Rabbit asked.  “No, I didn’t,” said Alice: “I don’t think it’s at all a pity. I said ‘What for?’”  “She boxed the Queen’s ears—” the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little scream of laughter. “Oh, hush!” the Rabbit whispered in a frightened tone. “The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said—”
paragraphs.summary: Alice corrects the Rabbit, saying she asked "What for?" not "What a pity!", and the Rabbit starts to explain that the Queen was boxed on the ears, prompting Alice to laugh and the Rabbit to whisper for her to be quiet, fearing the Queen will hear.

paragraphs.original: “Get to your places!” shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.  The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it _would_ twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.  The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen shouted "Get to your places!" and the chaotic game of croquet began, with players tumbling about before settling down. Alice struggled to manage her flamingo mallet, which kept twisting and looking up at her with a puzzled expression, while the hedgehog balls and soldiers caused further obstacles. The game descended into chaos, with players fighting for the hedgehogs and the Queen's temper flaring, prompting her to shout "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" repeatedly.

pages.page_summary: The Queen confirms that the missing heads are indeed gone, and then invites Alice to play croquet. Alice joins the game, accompanied by the White Rabbit, who is nervous and glancing at her face. The game quickly descends into chaos, with players struggling to manage their equipment, including a flamingo mallet that looks at Alice with a puzzled expression. The Queen's temper flares, and she repeatedly shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" as the game devolves into a violent and disorganized mess.

paragraphs.original: Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, “and then,” thought she, “what would become of me? They’re dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there’s any one left alive!”  She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself “It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.”  “How are you getting on?” said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
paragraphs.summary: Alice feels uneasy, anticipating a dispute with the Queen, and worries about the frequent beheadings in the area. She searches for an escape route, but instead notices the Cheshire Cat's grin in the air. The Cat speaks to her, asking how she's doing.

paragraphs.original: Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. “It’s no use speaking to it,” she thought, “till its ears have come, or at least one of them.” In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.  “I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”  “How do you like the Queen?” said the Cat in a low voice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice waited for the Cheshire Cat's ears to appear before speaking, then began explaining the confusing game of croquet to the Cat, complaining about the unfairness and chaos of the game, where the rules are ignored and living objects, like the hedgehog, interfere with play. The Cat asks Alice how she likes the Queen.

paragraphs.original: “Not at all,” said Alice: “she’s so extremely—” Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, “—likely to win, that it’s hardly worth while finishing the game.”  The Queen smiled and passed on.  “Who _are_ you talking to?” said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat’s head with great curiosity.
paragraphs.summary: Alice continues to discuss the Queen's chances of winning, but quickly stops when she realizes the Queen is listening. The Queen passes by, and the King approaches Alice, inquiring who she is talking to, and showing interest in the Cat's head.

paragraphs.original: “It’s a friend of mine—a Cheshire Cat,” said Alice: “allow me to introduce it.”  “I don’t like the look of it at all,” said the King: “however, it may kiss my hand if it likes.”  “I’d rather not,” the Cat remarked.
paragraphs.summary: Alice introduces the Cheshire Cat, a friend of hers, to the King, who is hesitant and asks the Cat to kiss his hand, but the Cat declines.

paragraphs.original: “Don’t be impertinent,” said the King, “and don’t look at me like that!” He got behind Alice as he spoke.  “A cat may look at a king,” said Alice. “I’ve read that in some book, but I don’t remember where.”  “Well, it must be removed,” said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, “My dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!”
paragraphs.summary: The King orders Alice not to be impertinent and to stop staring at him, then moves behind her. Alice quotes the phrase "A cat may look at a king" and claims to have read it in a book, but can't recall the title. The King insists the phrase be removed and summons the Queen to have the cat (presumably the one Alice is looking at) taken away.

pages.page_summary: Alice is anxious about a potential dispute with the Queen, who frequently orders beheadings. She's distracted by the Cheshire Cat's grin, which speaks to her. Alice explains the confusing and chaotic game of croquet to the Cat, complaining about the unfair rules and living objects interfering. The Cat asks about the Queen's chances of winning, but Alice stops when the Queen appears. The King approaches, inquiring about the Cat, and Alice introduces it as a friend. The King is hesitant and orders Alice to stop staring, but she quotes the phrase "A cat may look at a king" and claims to have read it in a book. The King summons the Queen to have the Cat taken away.

paragraphs.original: The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. “Off with his head!” she said, without even looking round.  “I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.  Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen, in her usual manner, sentences a player to death without hesitation, prompting the King to fetch the executioner. Alice, disliking the chaotic state of the game, decides to leave and search for her hedgehog companion.

paragraphs.original: The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.  By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: “but it doesn’t matter much,” thought Alice, “as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.” So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.  When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
paragraphs.summary: Alice observed a hedgehog fight, but by the time she retrieved her flamingo, the hedgehogs had disappeared. She then returned to the Cheshire Cat, where she found a large crowd gathered, with the executioner, King, and Queen engaged in a heated dispute, while the rest of the onlookers remained silent and uncomfortable.

paragraphs.original: The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.  The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at _his_ time of life.  The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.
paragraphs.summary: Alice is immediately asked to settle a dispute between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who are arguing over whether a head can be cut off without a body. The executioner claims it's impossible to behead something without a body, while the King insists that anything with a head can be beheaded, dismissing the executioner's concerns.

paragraphs.original: The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time she’d have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)  Alice could think of nothing else to say but “It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask _her_ about it.”  “She’s in prison,” the Queen said to the executioner: “fetch her here.” And the executioner went off like an arrow.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen threatens to execute everyone unless the issue is resolved quickly, prompting a grave and anxious atmosphere. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, who is in prison, about the matter, prompting the Queen to order the executioner to bring the Duchess to her.

paragraphs.original: The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.
paragraphs.summary: The Cat's head vanished as soon as he left, reappearing only when he returned with the Duchess; meanwhile, the King and executioner frantically searched for it, while the others resumed their game.

pages.page_summary: Alice leaves the chaotic game, searching for her hedgehog companion, but instead finds a crowd gathered around the Cheshire Cat, where the King, Queen, and executioner are arguing over whether a head can be cut off without a body. The Queen threatens to execute everyone unless the issue is resolved, prompting Alice to suggest asking the imprisoned Duchess for her opinion. The Cat's head disappears and reappears as the executioner fetches the Duchess, while the King and executioner search for the Cat's head, and the game resumes.

chapters.chapter_summary: Alice witnesses gardeners painting a white rose tree red, who reveal they'll be beheaded if the Queen finds out. The Queen demands to know Alice's identity, but Alice remains calm, thinking the Queen and her court are just a pack of cards. The Queen orders the gardeners' execution, but Alice intervenes, hiding them in a flower-pot. The Queen invites Alice to play croquet, which descends into chaos, with the Queen repeatedly shouting "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" Alice is anxious about the Queen's temper and beheadings, but is distracted by the Cheshire Cat's grin, which speaks to her. The Cat and Alice discuss the chaotic game, and Alice quotes the phrase "A cat may look at a king" to defend the Cat. The King orders the Cat taken away, but it disappears and reappears, leading to a dispute over whether a head can be cut off without a body. Alice suggests asking the imprisoned Duchess for her opinion, and the game resumes.

chapters.title: CHAPTER IX.

paragraphs.original: The Mock Turtle’s Story
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle, a melancholy creature, began to tell a story about his childhood with the Gryphon, a friend from his youth. They had been inseparable, sharing a love for swimming and playing in the river. However, their carefree days were disrupted by the arrival of the grinning Cheshire Cat, who would often appear and disappear, leaving the two friends bewildered. The Mock Turtle's tale was interrupted by the arrival of the Gryphon, who joined in, reminiscing about their time together and the lessons they learned from the wise old turtle, who taught them about the importance of friendship and the fleeting nature of life.

paragraphs.original: “You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.  Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.  “When _I’m_ a Duchess,” she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), “I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen _at all_. Soup does very well without—Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,” she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, “and vinegar that makes them sour—and camomile that makes them bitter—and—and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew _that_: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know—”
paragraphs.summary: The Duchess, now in a pleasant temper, greets Alice warmly and they walk together. Alice attributes the Duchess's earlier savagery to the pepper in the kitchen, and reflects on her own future as a Duchess, vowing to banish pepper and instead use soup as a substitute. She develops a theory that certain foods can influence people's tempers, such as pepper making them hot-tempered, vinegar sour, camomile bitter, and barley-sugar sweet-tempered.

paragraphs.original: She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. “You’re thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can’t tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.”  “Perhaps it hasn’t one,” Alice ventured to remark.  “Tut, tut, child!” said the Duchess. “Everything’s got a moral, if only you can find it.” And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice’s side as she spoke.
paragraphs.summary: The Duchess suddenly spoke to Alice, noticing she was lost in thought, and commented that people often forget to talk when they're thinking about something. Alice suggested that perhaps some things don't have a moral, but the Duchess disagreed, insisting that everything has a moral if one can just find it, and she moved closer to Alice.

paragraphs.original: Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was _very_ ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice’s shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.  “The game’s going on rather better now,” she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.  “’Tis so,” said the Duchess: “and the moral of that is—‘Oh, ’tis love, ’tis love, that makes the world go round!’”
paragraphs.summary: Alice dislikes sitting near the Duchess due to her ugliness and uncomfortably sharp chin, but tries to be polite. The Duchess comments on the game going well, and then quotes a phrase, "Oh, 'tis love, 'tis love, that makes the world go round!"

paragraphs.original: “Somebody said,” Alice whispered, “that it’s done by everybody minding their own business!”  “Ah, well! It means much the same thing,” said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice’s shoulder as she added, “and the moral of _that_ is—‘Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.’”  “How fond she is of finding morals in things!” Alice thought to herself.
paragraphs.summary: Alice overhears a comment that suggests chaos can be maintained by individuals focusing on their own affairs, but the Duchess rephrases it to emphasize the importance of prioritizing meaning over superficial details.

pages.page_summary: The Mock Turtle shares a story about his carefree childhood with the Gryphon, but their reminiscing is interrupted by the Gryphon's arrival. Meanwhile, the Duchess, now in a pleasant mood, greets Alice warmly and they walk together. Alice attributes the Duchess's earlier behavior to the pepper in the kitchen and develops a theory about how certain foods can influence people's tempers. The Duchess corrects Alice, insisting that everything has a moral, and they discuss the importance of finding meaning. Alice is uncomfortable sitting near the Duchess due to her appearance, but tries to be polite.

paragraphs.original: “I dare say you’re wondering why I don’t put my arm round your waist,” the Duchess said after a pause: “the reason is, that I’m doubtful about the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?”  “He might bite,” Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.  “Very true,” said the Duchess: “flamingoes and mustard both bite. And the moral of that is—‘Birds of a feather flock together.’”
paragraphs.summary: The Duchess suggests putting her arm around Alice, but hesitates due to concerns about the flamingo's temper, joking that it might bite, just like mustard. She then uses this as a teaching moment to illustrate the phrase "Birds of a feather flock together."

paragraphs.original: “Only mustard isn’t a bird,” Alice remarked.  “Right, as usual,” said the Duchess: “what a clear way you have of putting things!”  “It’s a mineral, I _think_,” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice makes a statement about mustard, saying it's not a bird, which the Duchess agrees with, complimenting Alice on her clear way of speaking. Alice then corrects herself, thinking mustard is actually a mineral.

paragraphs.original: “Of course it is,” said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; “there’s a large mustard-mine near here. And the moral of that is—‘The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.’”  “Oh, I know!” exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark, “it’s a vegetable. It doesn’t look like one, but it is.”  “I quite agree with you,” said the Duchess; “and the moral of that is—‘Be what you would seem to be’—or if you’d like it put more simply—‘Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.’”
paragraphs.summary: The Duchess agrees with Alice, citing a nearby mustard-mine as an example, and explains that the moral is "the more mine, the less yours." Alice misunderstands, thinking the mine is a vegetable, and the Duchess further confuses the matter with a convoluted moral about being what one appears to be.

paragraphs.original: “I think I should understand that better,” Alice said very politely, “if I had it written down: but I can’t quite follow it as you say it.”  “That’s nothing to what I could say if I chose,” the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.  “Pray don’t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice asks the Duchess to clarify her statement, but the Duchess responds that she could say even more if she wanted to, and Alice politely asks her to stop.

paragraphs.original: “Oh, don’t talk about trouble!” said the Duchess. “I make you a present of everything I’ve said as yet.”  “A cheap sort of present!” thought Alice. “I’m glad they don’t give birthday presents like that!” But she did not venture to say it out loud.  “Thinking again?” the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
paragraphs.summary: The Duchess offers Alice a "gift" of everything she's said so far, but Alice thinks it's a cheap present and is glad people don't give gifts like that on birthdays. The Duchess notices Alice's thoughts and asks if she's thinking again.

pages.page_summary: The Duchess suggests putting her arm around Alice, but hesitates due to the flamingo's temper. She uses this as a teaching moment to explain "Birds of a feather flock together." Alice corrects the Duchess's mustard analogy, initially thinking it's a bird, then a mineral, and the Duchess further confuses the matter with a convoluted moral. Alice politely asks the Duchess to clarify, but she continues to speak, eventually offering Alice a "gift" of her confusing statements, which Alice dismisses as a cheap present.

paragraphs.original: “I’ve a right to think,” said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.  “Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”  But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
paragraphs.summary: Alice expresses her right to think, but the Duchess cuts her off, comparing her right to a pig's ability to fly. However, the Duchess's voice trails off as the Queen suddenly appears, standing in front of them with a stern expression.

paragraphs.original: “A fine day, your Majesty!” the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.  “Now, I give you fair warning,” shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; “either you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time! Take your choice!”  The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
paragraphs.summary: The Duchess, speaking in a weak voice, greeted the Queen with a compliment, but the Queen responded by threatening to execute the Duchess unless she left immediately, giving her a choice between exile and beheading.

paragraphs.original: “Let’s go on with the game,” the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.  The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen’s absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment’s delay would cost them their lives.  All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen returns to the croquet game, prompting the other guests to hastily rejoin, despite her warning that delay will be fatal. The Queen continues to argue with the players, frequently shouting for the beheading of others, who are then taken into custody by the soldiers, leaving the game's infrastructure in disarray and ultimately resulting in the imprisonment of all players except the King, Queen, and Alice.

paragraphs.original: Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”  “No,” said Alice. “I don’t even know what a Mock Turtle is.”  “It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,” said the Queen.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen, out of breath, asked Alice if she had seen the Mock Turtle, to which Alice replied she had not and was unfamiliar with the creature, prompting the Queen to explain it was the ingredient used to make Mock Turtle Soup.

paragraphs.original: “I never saw one, or heard of one,” said Alice.  “Come on, then,” said the Queen, “and he shall tell you his history,”  As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, “You are all pardoned.” “Come, _that’s_ a good thing!” she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
paragraphs.summary: Alice expresses her surprise that she's never seen or heard of the executioner, prompting the Queen to invite her to meet him. As they walk away, the King quietly pardons the entire company, which Alice finds a welcome relief after witnessing the Queen's numerous executions.

pages.page_summary: The Duchess is cut off by the Queen, who appears with a stern expression and threatens to execute her unless she leaves. The Queen then returns to a chaotic croquet game, ordering the beheading of players and imprisoning most of them, except for the King, Queen, and Alice. After a brief respite, the Queen asks Alice about the Mock Turtle, explaining it's an ingredient in Mock Turtle Soup. Alice is then invited to meet the executioner, but the King intervenes, pardoning the entire company, bringing relief to Alice.

paragraphs.original: They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) “Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.  The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.  “What _is_ the fun?” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice and the Queen encounter a sleeping Gryphon, which the Queen orders to take Alice to see the Mock Turtle and hear its history. The Queen departs, leaving Alice with the Gryphon, who wakes up and watches the Queen leave before chuckling to itself. Alice asks the Gryphon what it finds amusing.

paragraphs.original: “Why, _she_,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”  “Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”  They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply. “What is his sorrow?” she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, “It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!”
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon dismisses Alice's concerns, saying the Mock Turtle's sorrow is just his imagination, and orders her to follow. Alice thinks to herself that everyone keeps saying "come on" and feels bossed around. As they approach the Mock Turtle, Alice sees him sitting alone, sighing deeply, and feels sorry for him. She asks the Gryphon about the Mock Turtle's sorrow, but the Gryphon again claims it's just his imagination.

paragraphs.original: So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.  “This here young lady,” said the Gryphon, “she wants for to know your history, she do.”  “I’ll tell it her,” said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: “sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished.”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle, with tears in his eyes, remained silent until the Gryphon prompted him to share his story, which he agreed to do, instructing the others to remain silent until he finished.

paragraphs.original: So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, “I don’t see how he can _ever_ finish, if he doesn’t begin.” But she waited patiently.  “Once,” said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, “I was a real Turtle.”  These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of “Hjckrrh!” from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, “Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,” but she could not help thinking there _must_ be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
paragraphs.summary: Alice and the Mock Turtle sat in silence for a few minutes, with the Gryphon occasionally exclaiming "Hjckrrh!" and the Mock Turtle sobbing heavily. The Mock Turtle finally began to speak, saying "Once I was a real Turtle," but then fell silent again, prompting Alice to wonder if there was more to the story.

paragraphs.original: “When we were little,” the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, “we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—”  “Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.  “We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily: “really you are very dull!”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle recounts his childhood education in the sea, where he attended school under the guidance of an old Turtle, nicknamed Tortoise, despite not being one, because he taught them.

pages.page_summary: Alice and the Queen encounter a sleeping Gryphon, who wakes up and takes Alice to meet the Mock Turtle. The Gryphon dismisses the Mock Turtle's sorrow as imagination, but Alice feels sorry for him. The Mock Turtle, prompted by the Gryphon, begins to share his story, recounting his childhood education in the sea under the guidance of an old Turtle named Tortoise.

paragraphs.original: “You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,” added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, “Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!” and he went on in these words:  “Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—”  “I never said I didn’t!” interrupted Alice.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon scolds Alice for asking a simple question, leaving her feeling embarrassed. The Gryphon then tells the Mock Turtle to continue their story, which begins with them attending school in the sea. Alice interrupts, correcting the Gryphon that she never doubted their claim.

paragraphs.original: “You did,” said the Mock Turtle.  “Hold your tongue!” added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.  “We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle continues speaking, stating that they and the Gryphon had excellent educations, attending school every day.

paragraphs.original: “_I’ve_ been to a day-school, too,” said Alice; “you needn’t be so proud as all that.”  “With extras?” asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.  “Yes,” said Alice, “we learned French and music.”
paragraphs.summary: Alice mentions she attended a day-school, where she learned French and music, and the Mock Turtle inquires if she had "extras" which implies additional classes.

paragraphs.original: “And washing?” said the Mock Turtle.  “Certainly not!” said Alice indignantly.  “Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,” said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. “Now at _ours_ they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, _and washing_—extra.’”
paragraphs.summary: Alice denies that her school included washing, prompting the Mock Turtle to express relief, implying that his own school, which listed "French, music, and washing—extra" on the bill, was more comprehensive.

paragraphs.original: “You couldn’t have wanted it much,” said Alice; “living at the bottom of the sea.”  “I couldn’t afford to learn it.” said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. “I only took the regular course.”  “What was that?” inquired Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice comments on the Mock Turtle's life, saying he couldn't have wanted it more, implying it's a difficult existence. The Mock Turtle responds that he couldn't afford to learn anything else, having only taken the standard course. Alice asks what that course entailed.

pages.page_summary: Alice feels embarrassed after the Gryphon scolds her, but the conversation continues with the Mock Turtle recounting their school days in the sea. Alice corrects the Gryphon, then shares about her own day-school experience, learning French and music. The Mock Turtle inquires about additional classes, and Alice denies having any, prompting the Mock Turtle to express relief about his own school's "extras" including washing. Alice sympathizes with the Mock Turtle's difficult life, and he reveals he couldn't afford to take extra courses.

paragraphs.original: “Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,” the Mock Turtle replied; “and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.”  “I never heard of ‘Uglification,’” Alice ventured to say. “What is it?”  The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. “What! Never heard of uglifying!” it exclaimed. “You know what to beautify is, I suppose?”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle explains that the branches of Arithmetic include Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision, with Alice unfamiliar with Uglification, prompting the Gryphon's surprise at her lack of knowledge.

paragraphs.original: “Yes,” said Alice doubtfully: “it means—to—make—anything—prettier.”  “Well, then,” the Gryphon went on, “if you don’t know what to uglify is, you _are_ a simpleton.”  Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said “What else had you to learn?”
paragraphs.summary: Alice expresses doubt about the meaning of "uglifying", which the Gryphon defines as making something prettier, prompting Alice to question her own understanding, and she then turns to the Mock Turtle to ask about his own education.

paragraphs.original: “Well, there was Mystery,” the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, “—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: _he_ taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.”  “What was _that_ like?” said Alice.  “Well, I can’t show it you myself,” the Mock Turtle said: “I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle explains to Alice that the subjects he studied at school included Mystery, Seaography, and Drawling, which was taught by a conger-eel instructor who also taught Stretching and Fainting in Coils.

paragraphs.original: “Hadn’t time,” said the Gryphon: “I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, _he_ was.”  “I never went to him,” the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: “he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.”  “So he did, so he did,” said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon and Mock Turtle reminisce about their Classics master, describing him as an old crab who taught Laughing and Grief, a subject that brings them both sadness.

paragraphs.original: “And how many hours a day did you do lessons?” said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.  “Ten hours the first day,” said the Mock Turtle: “nine the next, and so on.”  “What a curious plan!” exclaimed Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice quickly shifts the conversation by asking the Mock Turtle how many hours a day he spent on lessons, to which he responds that he started with 10 hours the first day, then reduced it to 9 hours the next day, and so on. Alice finds this plan peculiar.

pages.page_summary: Alice learns about the branches of Arithmetic from the Mock Turtle, which include Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision. She's unfamiliar with Uglification, leading to a discussion about its meaning. The Mock Turtle shares his education, which included subjects like Mystery, Seaography, and Drawling, taught by a conger-eel instructor. The Gryphon and Mock Turtle reminisce about their Classics master, an old crab who taught Laughing and Grief, before Alice shifts the conversation to the Mock Turtle's lesson schedule, which he reduced by one hour each day.

paragraphs.original: “That’s the reason they’re called lessons,” the Gryphon remarked: “because they lessen from day to day.”  This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. “Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?”  “Of course it was,” said the Mock Turtle.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon explains that lessons are called as such because they decrease in difficulty over time, a concept that puzzles Alice. She then asks if the eleventh day, which was a holiday, was a day off from lessons, to which the Mock Turtle agrees.

paragraphs.original: “And how did you manage on the twelfth?” Alice went on eagerly.  “That’s enough about lessons,” the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: “tell her something about the games now.”
paragraphs.summary: Alice asks the Gryphon about his experience on the twelfth day, but he cuts her off to discuss the games they played instead.

pages.page_summary: Alice is confused about the concept of lessons decreasing in difficulty over time, and asks if the eleventh day, a holiday, was a day off from lessons. The Mock Turtle confirms this, and the Gryphon changes the subject to discuss the games they played on the twelfth day.

chapters.chapter_summary:
Alice spends time with the Duchess, who shares her thoughts on morality and the importance of finding meaning. However, their conversation is interrupted by the Queen, who threatens to execute the Duchess unless she leaves. The Queen then returns to a chaotic croquet game, ordering the beheading of players and imprisoning most. Alice is eventually pardoned along with the King and Queen.

Alice meets the Mock Turtle, who shares a story about his childhood education in the sea under the guidance of an old Turtle named Tortoise. The Mock Turtle recounts his school days, including learning subjects like Mystery, Seaography, and Drawling from a conger-eel instructor. Alice learns about the branches of Arithmetic, which include Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision, and discusses the meaning of Uglification with the Mock Turtle.

The Gryphon and Mock Turtle reminisce about their Classics master, an old crab who taught Laughing and Grief, before Alice shifts the conversation to the Mock Turtle's lesson schedule, which he reduced by one hour each day. Alice is confused about the concept of lessons decreasing in difficulty over time and asks if the eleventh day, a holiday, was a day off from lessons.

chapters.title: CHAPTER X.

paragraphs.original: The Lobster Quadrille
paragraphs.summary: In a fantastical and absurd world, the Lobster Quadrille is a dance performed by those who have not found a mate within a specified time, forcing them to choose between being turned into a lobster and being executed. The dance is a desperate attempt to find a partner, with the dancers moving in a repetitive and mechanical manner, their faces frozen in a mixture of fear and resignation.

paragraphs.original: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. “Same as if he had a bone in his throat,” said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:—  “You may not have lived much under the sea—” (“I haven’t,” said Alice)—“and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—” (Alice began to say “I once tasted—” but checked herself hastily, and said “No, never”) “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle, overcome with emotion, struggles to speak, but eventually composes himself to explain to Alice that she, having never lived under the sea, cannot appreciate the delight of a Lobster Quadrille.

paragraphs.original: “No, indeed,” said Alice. “What sort of a dance is it?”  “Why,” said the Gryphon, “you first form into a line along the sea-shore—”  “Two lines!” cried the Mock Turtle. “Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—”
paragraphs.summary: Alice inquires about the nature of a dance, prompting the Gryphon to explain that it involves forming a line along the sea-shore, while the Mock Turtle interrupts to add that the line consists of various sea creatures, including seals, turtles, and salmon, which must first clear the jellyfish from their path.

paragraphs.original: “_That_ generally takes some time,” interrupted the Gryphon.  “—you advance twice—”  “Each with a lobster as a partner!” cried the Gryphon.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon interrupts, explaining that advancing twice typically takes time, and adds that each advance is accompanied by a lobster as a partner.

paragraphs.original: “Of course,” the Mock Turtle said: “advance twice, set to partners—”  “—change lobsters, and retire in same order,” continued the Gryphon.  “Then, you know,” the Mock Turtle went on, “you throw the—”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle and the Gryphon continue explaining the rules of a game, with the Mock Turtle saying to advance twice and set to partners, and the Gryphon adding to change lobsters and retire in the same order, before the Mock Turtle mentions throwing something.

pages.page_summary: In a bizarre world, the Lobster Quadrille is a dance performed by those who haven't found a mate within a time limit, forcing them to choose between being turned into a lobster or executed. The dance is a desperate attempt to find a partner, with dancers moving in a repetitive and mechanical manner. The Mock Turtle explains the dance to Alice, who is unfamiliar with it, and is aided by the Gryphon. The dance involves forming a line of sea creatures, clearing jellyfish, advancing twice, and changing partners, with lobsters accompanying the dancers.

paragraphs.original: “The lobsters!” shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.  “—as far out to sea as you can—”  “Swim after them!” screamed the Gryphon.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon shouts "The lobsters!" and bounds into the air, instructing Alice to swim after them as far out to sea as possible.

paragraphs.original: “Turn a somersault in the sea!” cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.  “Change lobsters again!” yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.  “Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle and Gryphon, still excited from their earlier antics, suddenly calm down and sit down beside Alice, their earlier cries of "Turn a somersault in the sea!" and "Change lobsters again!" replaced by a somber silence.

paragraphs.original: “It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.  “Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.  “Very much indeed,” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice expresses interest in the dance, and the Mock Turtle offers to show her a little of it.

paragraphs.original: “Come, let’s try the first figure!” said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon. “We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?”  “Oh, _you_ sing,” said the Gryphon. “I’ve forgotten the words.”  So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:—
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle and Gryphon invite Alice to watch them perform a dance, suggesting they can skip the lobster part, and decide the Mock Turtle will sing, despite the Gryphon admitting to forgetting the words. They begin dancing around Alice, occasionally stepping on her toes, while the Mock Turtle sings a slow and sorrowful tune.

paragraphs.original: “Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail. “There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail. See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance! They are waiting on the shingle—will you come and join the dance? Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance? Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?  “You can really have no notion how delightful it will be When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!” But the snail replied “Too far, too far!” and gave a look askance— Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.  “What matters it how far we go?” his scaly friend replied. “There is another shore, you know, upon the other side. The further off from England the nearer is to France— Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance. Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance? Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”
paragraphs.summary: A whiting urges a snail to join a dance on the beach, warning of a porpoise behind them, but the snail declines, citing the distance to the sea as too far. The whiting persists, suggesting that the farther they go from England, the closer they'll be to France, but the snail remains uninterested.

pages.page_summary: Alice is instructed by the Gryphon to chase lobsters out to sea, but the Mock Turtle and Gryphon soon calm down and sit with her. They offer to teach her a dance, with the Mock Turtle singing a slow and sorrowful tune while they dance around her. Meanwhile, a whiting tries to convince a snail to join a beach dance, but the snail declines, citing the distance to the sea.

paragraphs.original: “Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”  “Oh, as to the whiting,” said the Mock Turtle, “they—you’ve seen them, of course?”
paragraphs.summary: Alice expresses relief that the dance is over and enjoys the song about the whiting, while the Mock Turtle asks if she's familiar with the whiting.

paragraphs.original: “Yes,” said Alice, “I’ve often seen them at dinn—” she checked herself hastily.  “I don’t know where Dinn may be,” said the Mock Turtle, “but if you’ve seen them so often, of course you know what they’re like.”  “I believe so,” Alice replied thoughtfully. “They have their tails in their mouths—and they’re all over crumbs.”
paragraphs.summary: Alice mentions seeing creatures with tails in their mouths and covered in crumbs, but quickly corrects herself, unsure of the location "Dinn" where she's seen them. The Mock Turtle questions her familiarity with these creatures, and Alice thinks she knows what they look like.

paragraphs.original: “You’re wrong about the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle: “crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they _have_ their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—” here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.—“Tell her about the reason and all that,” he said to the Gryphon.  “The reason is,” said the Gryphon, “that they _would_ go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn’t get them out again. That’s all.”  “Thank you,” said Alice, “it’s very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle and Gryphon explain to Alice that the reason the whiting have their tails in their mouths is that they were thrown out to sea and fell a long way, causing their tails to get stuck in their mouths.

paragraphs.original: “I can tell you more than that, if you like,” said the Gryphon. “Do you know why it’s called a whiting?”  “I never thought about it,” said Alice. “Why?”  “_It does the boots and shoes_,” the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon offers to explain the origin of the term "whiting" to Alice, asking if she knows why it's called that, and then solemnly reveals that it's because the whiting does the boots and shoes.

paragraphs.original: Alice was thoroughly puzzled. “Does the boots and shoes!” she repeated in a wondering tone.  “Why, what are _your_ shoes done with?” said the Gryphon. “I mean, what makes them so shiny?”  Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. “They’re done with blacking, I believe.”
paragraphs.summary: Alice is perplexed and asks the Gryphon why her shoes are so shiny, to which he responds by asking what she means by "done with". Alice then explains that she thinks they were polished with blacking.

pages.page_summary: Alice is relieved the dance is over and enjoys a song about the whiting, but the Mock Turtle questions her familiarity with the fish. Alice recalls seeing creatures with tails in their mouths, but corrects herself, unsure of the location. The Mock Turtle and Gryphon explain that the whiting's tails got stuck in their mouths after falling from a great height. The Gryphon also explains the origin of the term "whiting", saying it's because the fish does the boots and shoes, leaving Alice perplexed.

paragraphs.original: “Boots and shoes under the sea,” the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, “are done with a whiting. Now you know.”  “And what are they made of?” Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.  “Soles and eels, of course,” the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: “any shrimp could have told you that.”
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon explains that sea boots and shoes are made with a whiting, and when asked what they're made of, he responds that they're composed of soles and eels, implying that this information is obvious.

paragraphs.original: “If I’d been the whiting,” said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, “I’d have said to the porpoise, ‘Keep back, please: we don’t want _you_ with us!’”  “They were obliged to have him with them,” the Mock Turtle said: “no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.”  “Wouldn’t it really?” said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
paragraphs.summary: Alice imagines telling a porpoise to stay away, but the Mock Turtle explains that a porpoise is necessary for a wise fish, implying it's a required companion.

paragraphs.original: “Of course not,” said the Mock Turtle: “why, if a fish came to _me_, and told me he was going a journey, I should say ‘With what porpoise?’”  “Don’t you mean ‘purpose’?” said Alice.  “I mean what I say,” the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of _your_ adventures.”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle dismisses the idea of a fish going on a journey, asking instead "With what porpoise?" in a sarcastic tone, to which Alice corrects him to "purpose." The Mock Turtle insists on his original word choice, and the Gryphon intervenes, suggesting they hear some of Alice's own adventures.

paragraphs.original: “I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,” said Alice a little timidly: “but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.”  “Explain all that,” said the Mock Turtle.  “No, no! The adventures first,” said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: “explanations take such a dreadful time.”
paragraphs.summary: Alice hesitantly offers to recount her adventures, but the Mock Turtle asks her to explain herself first, while the Gryphon insists she share her stories immediately, as explanations take too long.

paragraphs.original: So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so _very_ wide, but she gained courage as she went on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating “_You are old, Father William_,” to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said “That’s very curious.”  “It’s all about as curious as it can be,” said the Gryphon.  “It all came different!” the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. “I should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to begin.” He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice recounts her adventures to the two creatures, initially nervous but gaining confidence as she speaks. Her listeners remain silent until she mentions repeating "You are old, Father William" to the Caterpillar, with the words coming out differently, prompting the Mock Turtle to comment on its curiosity. The Gryphon agrees, and the Mock Turtle suggests Alice try repeating something again, looking to the Gryphon for authority.

pages.page_summary: Alice's conversation with the Gryphon and Mock Turtle involves a discussion about the composition of sea boots and shoes, with the Gryphon implying they're made of eels. The Mock Turtle uses wordplay to question the idea of a fish going on a journey, and the Gryphon intervenes to suggest Alice share her own adventures. Alice recounts her experiences, initially hesitant but gaining confidence, and her listeners remain silent until she mentions repeating a phrase to the Caterpillar, which sparks their interest.

paragraphs.original: “Stand up and repeat ‘’_Tis the voice of the sluggard_,’” said the Gryphon.  “How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!” thought Alice; “I might as well be at school at once.” However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:—  “’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare, “You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.” As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.”
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon orders Alice to stand up and repeat the phrase "_Tis the voice of the sluggard_," but Alice's mind is preoccupied with the Lobster Quadrille and she ends up mangling the words, replacing "sluggard" with "Lobster" and creating a nonsensical phrase.

paragraphs.original: [later editions continued as follows When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark, And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark, But, when the tide rises and sharks are around, His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.]   “That’s different from what _I_ used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
paragraphs.summary: The character's demeanor changes dramatically depending on his surroundings, speaking with confidence and contempt when alone, but becoming timid and fearful when sharks are present, a stark contrast to his earlier carefree self.

paragraphs.original: “Well, I never heard it before,” said the Mock Turtle; “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”  Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would _ever_ happen in a natural way again.  “I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle.
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle expresses skepticism about the nonsense he's heard, while Alice remains silent, lost in thought, and the Mock Turtle requests an explanation.

paragraphs.original: “She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”  “But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted. “How _could_ he turn them out with his nose, you know?”  “It’s the first position in dancing.” Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon hastily interrupts the Mock Turtle, urging him to continue with the next verse, but the Mock Turtle persists in questioning the absurdity of the Mad Hatter's dancing, specifically how he could turn out his toes with his nose. Alice tries to deflect the conversation by explaining that it's the first position in dancing, but is clearly perplexed by the situation.

paragraphs.original: “Go on with the next verse,” the Gryphon repeated impatiently: “it begins ‘_I passed by his garden_.’”  Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—  “I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye, How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon impatiently prompts Alice to continue the next verse, which begins with the line "I passed by his garden." Alice hesitantly obeys, reciting the verse in a trembling voice, starting with the line "I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye, How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie."

pages.page_summary: Alice struggles to repeat a phrase as instructed by the Gryphon, mangling the words due to her preoccupation with the Lobster Quadrille. The Gryphon's demeanor changes depending on his surroundings, revealing a timid and fearful side when sharks are present. The Mock Turtle questions the absurdity of the Mad Hatter's dancing, prompting the Gryphon to interrupt and urge him to continue. Alice tries to deflect the conversation, but eventually recites the next verse in a trembling voice, starting with "I passed by his garden" and describing a surreal scene with the Owl and Panther sharing a pie.

paragraphs.original: [later editions continued as follows The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat, While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat. When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon, Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon: While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl, And concluded the banquet—]   “What _is_ the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s by far the most confusing thing _I_ ever heard!”
paragraphs.summary: The Panther and Owl finish their meal, with the Owl getting the spoon as a bonus, while the Panther is given the knife and fork with a growl. The Mock Turtle interrupts, criticizing the repetition of details without explanation.

paragraphs.original: “Yes, I think you’d better leave off,” said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.  “Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon went on. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”  “Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,” Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, “Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her ‘_Turtle Soup_,’ will you, old fellow?”
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon suggests Alice leave, but she's relieved to stay. He proposes they try another dance, the Lobster Quadrille, or have the Mock Turtle sing a song, which Alice eagerly chooses.

paragraphs.original: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—  “Beautiful Soup, so rich and green, Waiting in a hot tureen! Who for such dainties would not stoop? Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!     Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!     Beau—ootiful Soo—oop! Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!  “Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish, Game, or any other dish? Who would not give all else for two p ennyworth only of beautiful Soup? Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?     Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!     Beau—ootiful Soo—oop! Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,     Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!”
paragraphs.summary: The Mock Turtle, overcome with emotion, sings a poignant song about a beautiful soup, rich and green, waiting in a hot tureen, and how it's worth giving up all other dishes for, even if it only costs two pence.

paragraphs.original: “Chorus again!” cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of “The trial’s beginning!” was heard in the distance.  “Come on!” cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
paragraphs.summary: The Gryphon interrupts the Mock Turtle's song, shouting "Chorus again!" and then a cry of "The trial's beginning!" is heard in the distance, prompting the Gryphon to hurry off with Alice in tow.

paragraphs.original: “What trial is it?” Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered “Come on!” and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—  “Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”
paragraphs.summary: Alice asks the Gryphon what trial they are running towards, but he just encourages her to keep going, increasing his pace. Meanwhile, a faint, sorrowful chant carried by the wind grows louder, repeating the phrase "Soo—oop of the e—e—evening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!"

pages.page_summary: Alice stays with the Gryphon and Mock Turtle, who sing a song about a beautiful soup. The Gryphon interrupts, and they hear a cry that the trial is beginning, prompting them to hurry off with Alice. The Gryphon doesn't explain the trial, but Alice continues to follow him as a faint chant about the soup grows louder in the distance.

chapters.chapter_summary: Alice learns about the Lobster Quadrille, a desperate dance performed by those who haven't found a mate, where dancers move in a repetitive manner to find a partner. The Gryphon and Mock Turtle teach her a dance, singing a sorrowful tune, while explaining the origin of the whiting's name and the composition of sea boots and shoes. Alice shares her adventures, initially hesitant but gaining confidence, and her listeners become interested when she mentions repeating a phrase to the Caterpillar. The Gryphon's demeanor changes depending on his surroundings, revealing a timid side when sharks are present. Alice struggles to repeat a phrase, mangling the words, and eventually recites a verse about a surreal scene with the Owl and Panther. The Gryphon and Mock Turtle sing a song about a beautiful soup, but are interrupted by a cry that the trial is beginning, prompting them to hurry off with Alice.

chapters.title: CHAPTER XI.

paragraphs.original: Who Stole the Tarts?
paragraphs.summary: The White Rabbit, in a state of panic, accused a group of mice of stealing the tarts from the Duchess's kitchen, despite the fact that the mice were actually just trying to find crumbs to eat.

paragraphs.original: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—“I wish they’d get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!” But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.  Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. “That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “because of his great wig.”
paragraphs.summary: The King and Queen of Hearts sat on their throne, surrounded by a crowd of little birds, beasts, and playing cards, including the chained Knave and guarded soldiers. The White Rabbit stood nearby, holding a trumpet and parchment. A table in the center of the court held a large dish of tarts, making Alice hungry. As the trial seemed to drag on, Alice looked around, recognizing the judge by his large wig, despite never having attended a court of justice before.

paragraphs.original: The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.  “And that’s the jury-box,” thought Alice, “and those twelve creatures,” (she was obliged to say “creatures,” you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) “I suppose they are the jurors.” She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.  The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”
paragraphs.summary: The King, who was also the judge, wore his crown over a wig, appearing somewhat uncomfortable. Alice observed the jury-box and twelve jurors, some of whom were animals or birds, writing on slates.
