She was proud to have learned the word "jurors" and wondered why they were writing before the trial began.

paragraphs.original: “They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply, “for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”  “Stupid things!” Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, “Silence in the court!” and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.  Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down “stupid things!” on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell “stupid,” and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice's loud outburst is silenced by the White Rabbit's order, and the jurors are secretly writing down "stupid things" on their slates, with one juror struggling to spell the word and needing help from a neighbor.

paragraphs.original: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could _not_ stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.  “Herald, read the accusation!” said the King.  On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
paragraphs.summary: Alice disrupts a juror, Bill the Lizard, by taking his squeaky pencil, forcing him to write with his finger, which leaves no mark on the slate. The King then orders the White Rabbit to read the accusation, which the Rabbit does by blowing three blasts on the trumpet and unrolling a parchment scroll.

pages.page_summary: The White Rabbit accuses a group of mice of stealing tarts from the Duchess's kitchen, but they were only trying to find crumbs. The King and Queen of Hearts preside over a chaotic court, surrounded by a crowd of creatures, including the chained Knave and guarded soldiers. Alice, hungry and observing, recognizes the judge and notes the jurors writing on slates before the trial begins. The jurors are secretly writing "stupid things" and one struggles to spell a word. Alice disrupts a juror, Bill the Lizard, by taking his pencil, and the White Rabbit reads the accusation by blowing on a trumpet and unrolling a parchment.

paragraphs.original: “The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,     All on a summer day: The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,     And took them quite away!”   “Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen of Hearts baked tarts on a summer day, but the Knave of Hearts stole them, taking them away. The King then instructed the jury to consider their verdict.

paragraphs.original: “Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to come before that!”  “Call the first witness,” said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, “First witness!”  The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I beg pardon, your Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.”
paragraphs.summary: The White Rabbit interrupts the King, saying "Not yet, not yet!" and insists that there's more to come before proceeding. The King orders the White Rabbit to call the first witness, who is the Hatter. The Hatter enters, holding a teacup and a piece of bread-and-butter, and apologizes for bringing them in, explaining that he hadn't finished his tea when summoned.

paragraphs.original: “You ought to have finished,” said the King. “When did you begin?”  The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. “Fourteenth of March, I _think_ it was,” he said.  “Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.
paragraphs.summary: The King scolds the Hatter for not finishing something, asking when he started. The Hatter and March Hare discuss the date they began, with the Hatter thinking it was the 14th and the Hare correcting him to the 15th.

paragraphs.original: “Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.  “Write that down,” the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.  “Take off your hat,” the King said to the Hatter.
paragraphs.summary: The Dormouse states the number "sixteenth", prompting the King to instruct the jury to record the date. The jury writes down the date, adds it to two other dates, and calculates the total in shillings and pence. The King then tells the Hatter to remove his hat.

paragraphs.original: “It isn’t mine,” said the Hatter.  “_Stolen!_” the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.  “I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none of my own. I’m a hatter.”
paragraphs.summary: The Hatter denies ownership of the stolen items, explaining that he sells them and has none of his own, as he is a hatter by profession.

pages.page_summary: The Queen of Hearts bakes tarts, but the Knave of Hearts steals them. The King orders the jury to consider the verdict, but the White Rabbit interrupts, saying there's more to come. The King summons the Hatter as the first witness, who enters with a teacup and bread-and-butter, apologizing for not finishing his tea. The Hatter and March Hare discuss the date they started something, with the Hatter initially thinking it was the 14th, but the Hare correcting him to the 15th. The Dormouse states the date as the 16th, and the jury records it, calculating the total in shillings and pence. The King then orders the Hatter to remove his hat, and the Hatter denies owning the stolen items, explaining he sells them as a hatter.

paragraphs.original: Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.  “Give your evidence,” said the King; “and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.”  This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen donned her spectacles and fixed her gaze on the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted. The King ordered the Hatter to provide his evidence, warning him not to be nervous or he would be executed immediately, but the Hatter's anxiety only worsened, causing him to accidentally bite a chunk out of his teacup instead of his bread-and-butter.

paragraphs.original: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.  “I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. “I can hardly breathe.”  “I can’t help it,” said Alice very meekly: “I’m growing.”
paragraphs.summary: Alice experiences a curious sensation as she begins to grow larger again, initially considering leaving the court but deciding to stay as long as possible. The Dormouse next to her complains about being squeezed, prompting Alice to apologize meekly, explaining that she's growing.

paragraphs.original: “You’ve no right to grow _here_,” said the Dormouse.  “Don’t talk nonsense,” said Alice more boldly: “you know you’re growing too.”  “Yes, but _I_ grow at a reasonable pace,” said the Dormouse: “not in that ridiculous fashion.” And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.
paragraphs.summary: The Dormouse tells Alice she has no right to grow in the court, but Alice retorts that the Dormouse is growing too, albeit at a slow pace. The Dormouse defends his growth, claiming it's reasonable, and then sulkily moves to the other side of the court.

paragraphs.original: All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.  “Give your evidence,” the King repeated angrily, “or I’ll have you executed, whether you’re nervous or not.”  “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, “—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—”
paragraphs.summary: The Queen continues to stare at the Hatter, and as the Dormouse passes by, she orders an officer to bring her the list of singers from the last concert. The Hatter, visibly shaken, trembles so hard that he loses his shoes. The King demands that the Hatter give his evidence, threatening to execute him if he doesn't, despite the Hatter's claim of being a poor man and still in the middle of his tea.

paragraphs.original: “The twinkling of the _what?_” said the King.  “It _began_ with the tea,” the Hatter replied.  “Of course twinkling begins with a T!” said the King sharply. “Do you take me for a dunce? Go on!”
paragraphs.summary: The King asks the Hatter to continue, after the Hatter mentions that the twinkling began with the tea, and the King corrects him, saying that twinkling starts with the letter T.

pages.page_summary: The Queen scrutinizes the Hatter, who becomes increasingly agitated, biting his teacup instead of his bread-and-butter. Meanwhile, Alice grows larger again, apologizing to the Dormouse for the discomfort she causes. The Dormouse disputes Alice's right to grow in the court, but Alice counters that he is growing too, albeit slowly. The Queen's attention remains fixed on the Hatter, who is ordered to provide evidence, despite his claims of poverty and being in the middle of his tea. The King threatens execution if the Hatter fails to comply, and the scene descends into chaos as the Hatter loses his shoes and the Queen demands a list of singers from the last concert.

paragraphs.original: “I’m a poor man,” the Hatter went on, “and most things twinkled after that—only the March Hare said—”  “I didn’t!” the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.  “You did!” said the Hatter.
paragraphs.summary: The Hatter claims to be a poor man, but the March Hare disputes this, with the Hatter insisting the March Hare had previously acknowledged his poverty.

paragraphs.original: “I deny it!” said the March Hare.  “He denies it,” said the King: “leave out that part.”  “Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said—” the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
paragraphs.summary: The March Hare denies a statement, but the King instructs the Hatter to omit it. The Hatter then attempts to continue, referencing the Dormouse, but the Dormouse remains asleep and denies nothing.

paragraphs.original: “After that,” continued the Hatter, “I cut some more bread-and-butter—”  “But what did the Dormouse say?” one of the jury asked.  “That I can’t remember,” said the Hatter.
paragraphs.summary: The Hatter continues speaking, mentioning that he cut more bread-and-butter, but is then interrupted by a jury member who asks about the Dormouse's statement, to which the Hatter responds that he can't recall.

paragraphs.original: “You _must_ remember,” remarked the King, “or I’ll have you executed.”  The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” he began.  “You’re a _very_ poor _speaker_,” said the King.
paragraphs.summary: The King threatens to execute the Hatter if he doesn't remember something, prompting the Hatter to drop his teacup and kneel in fear, before the King insults his speaking abilities.

paragraphs.original: Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)  “I’m glad I’ve seen that done,” thought Alice. “I’ve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, “There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court,” and I never understood what it meant till now.”  “If that’s all you know about it, you may stand down,” continued the King.
paragraphs.summary: A guinea-pig in the courtroom cheered, but was quickly silenced by being stuffed into a canvas bag and sat upon by the officers. Alice, who had previously read about such attempts at applause being suppressed, is now enlightened. The King orders the guinea-pig to be dismissed.

pages.page_summary: The Hatter and March Hare engage in a dispute over the Hatter's poverty, with the March Hare denying the Hatter's claims. The King intervenes, instructing the Hatter to omit certain statements. The Hatter continues speaking, but is interrupted by a jury member and the King, who threatens to execute him if he can't recall a statement. The Hatter panics, dropping his teacup and kneeling in fear. Meanwhile, a guinea-pig in the courtroom attempts to cheer, but is quickly silenced and dismissed by the King.

paragraphs.original: “I can’t go no lower,” said the Hatter: “I’m on the floor, as it is.”  “Then you may _sit_ down,” the King replied.  Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
paragraphs.summary: The Hatter claims he's already at the lowest point, on the floor, and the King suggests he sit down, prompting a brief cheer from another guinea-pig that is quickly silenced.

paragraphs.original: “Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!” thought Alice. “Now we shall get on better.”  “I’d rather finish my tea,” said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.  “You may go,” said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
paragraphs.summary: Alice thinks the guinea-pigs' execution will improve the situation, but the Hatter prefers to finish his tea first, glancing nervously at the Queen, who's reading a list of singers. The King dismisses the Hatter, who hastily exits without even putting on his shoes.

paragraphs.original: “—and just take his head off outside,” the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.  “Call the next witness!” said the King.  The next witness was the Duchess’s cook. She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen orders an officer to take the Hatter's head outside, but he disappears before the officer can act. The King then calls the next witness, the Duchess's cook, who is recognizable by the sneezing crowd near the door, as she carries a pepper-box.

paragraphs.original: “Give your evidence,” said the King.  “Shan’t,” said the cook.  The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, “Your Majesty must cross-examine _this_ witness.”
paragraphs.summary: The King demands evidence from the cook, but the cook refuses to provide it. The King looks to the White Rabbit for guidance, who advises him to question the cook directly.

paragraphs.original: “Well, if I must, I must,” the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, “What are tarts made of?”  “Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.  “Treacle,” said a sleepy voice behind her.
paragraphs.summary: The King, with a somber expression, asked the cook what tarts are made of, prompting her to reply that they are primarily made of pepper. A second voice, likely from a nearby person, chimed in, adding that treacle is also a key ingredient.

pages.page_summary: The Hatter is dismissed by the King, but before he can be taken away, he escapes. The King then calls the Duchess's cook as the next witness, who is recognizable by her sneezing entourage. The cook refuses to provide evidence, prompting the King to question her directly about the ingredients of the Duchess's tarts, which she reveals are primarily made of pepper, with treacle also being a key ingredient.

paragraphs.original: “Collar that Dormouse,” the Queen shrieked out. “Behead that Dormouse! Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!”  For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.  “Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.” And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, _you_ must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”
paragraphs.summary: The Queen orders the beheading of a Dormouse, causing chaos in the court, but the King intervenes, dismissing the Dormouse and instructing the Queen to cross-examine the next witness, suggesting she is the one who should be handling the questioning.

paragraphs.original: Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like, “—for they haven’t got much evidence _yet_,” she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name “Alice!”
paragraphs.summary: Alice observes the White Rabbit struggling with a list, feeling curious about the next witness. She notes that the Rabbit's voice is shrill as he reads out the name "Alice" as the first witness.

pages.page_summary: The Queen's order to behead a Dormouse sparks chaos in the court, but the King intervenes, dismissing the Dormouse and instructing the Queen to question the next witness. Meanwhile, Alice observes the White Rabbit struggling with a list, and is called as the first witness, with the Rabbit reading out her name in a shrill voice.

chapters.chapter_summary: In a chaotic court, the White Rabbit accuses a group of mice of stealing tarts, but they were only searching for crumbs. The King and Queen of Hearts preside over the trial, surrounded by a crowd of creatures, including the chained Knave and guarded soldiers. Alice observes the trial, noting the jurors writing on slates and the White Rabbit reading the accusation. The trial descends into chaos as the Hatter is questioned about the stolen tarts, with the Queen scrutinizing him and the King threatening execution. The Hatter denies owning the stolen items, but the Queen demands evidence, leading to a dispute over his poverty. The Hatter is eventually dismissed, but escapes before being taken away. The King then calls the Duchess's cook as the next witness, who reveals the ingredients of the Duchess's tarts. The trial continues with Alice being called as the first witness, with the White Rabbit reading out her name.

chapters.title: CHAPTER XII.

paragraphs.original: Alice’s Evidence
paragraphs.summary: Alice, a young woman, is accused of murdering her husband, Edward, in a small English village. The local doctor, who had been treating Edward for a mysterious illness, is called to testify, but his evidence is inconclusive. The doctor's testimony is further complicated by his own troubled past, which is slowly revealed through the questioning.

paragraphs.original: “Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.  “Oh, I _beg_ your pardon!” she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.  “The trial cannot proceed,” said the King in a very grave voice, “until all the jurymen are back in their proper places—_all_,” he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
paragraphs.summary: Alice, in her haste, knocked over the jury-box, sending the jurymen tumbling into the crowd below, where they lay sprawled out. Reminded of a previous mishap with a goldfish, Alice frantically gathered the jurymen, fearing they would die if not returned to the box. The King intervened, declaring the trial could not proceed until all the jurymen were back in their proper places.

paragraphs.original: Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got it out again, and put it right; “not that it signifies much,” she said to herself; “I should think it would be _quite_ as much use in the trial one way up as the other.”  As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.  “What do you know about this business?” the King said to Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice corrected her mistake by removing the Lizard from the jury-box, which she had placed head downwards, and put it right-side up. The jury, still shaken from being upset, began to write a report of the incident, except for the Lizard, which was too distraught to participate. The King then asked Alice what she knew about the situation.

paragraphs.original: “Nothing,” said Alice.  “Nothing _whatever?_” persisted the King.  “Nothing whatever,” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice denies the King's question, insisting that there is indeed nothing, with the King pressing her for a more definitive answer.

paragraphs.original: “That’s very important,” the King said, turning to the jury. They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted: “_Un_important, your Majesty means, of course,” he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.  “_Un_important, of course, I meant,” the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone,  “important—unimportant—unimportant—important—” as if he were trying which word sounded best.
paragraphs.summary: The King clarifies that something is very important, but the White Rabbit corrects him, suggesting he meant to say it's unimportant, while making disapproving faces. The King hastily agrees, then mutters to himself, weighing the two words.

pages.page_summary: Alice, accused of murdering her husband, is on trial in a small English village. The local doctor's testimony is inconclusive due to his troubled past. Meanwhile, chaos erupts in the courtroom as Alice accidentally knocks over the jury box, sending jurors tumbling into the crowd. The King intervenes, halting the trial until the jurors are restored. Alice corrects her mistake by removing a Lizard from the box, but the jurors are shaken and unable to write a report. The King presses Alice for information about the situation, but she denies knowing anything. The King's words are later corrected by the White Rabbit, who suggests that what he meant to say was that something is unimportant, not important.

paragraphs.original: Some of the jury wrote it down “important,” and some “unimportant.” Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; “but it doesn’t matter a bit,” she thought to herself.  At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_.”  Everybody looked at Alice.
paragraphs.summary: The jury members scribbled "important" or "unimportant" on their slates, but Alice noticed, as she stood nearby. The King suddenly interrupted, shouting "Silence!" and read from his notebook, citing Rule Forty-two, which stated that anyone over a mile high must leave the court, prompting everyone to look at Alice.

paragraphs.original: “_I’m_ not a mile high,” said Alice.  “You are,” said the King.  “Nearly two miles high,” added the Queen.
paragraphs.summary: Alice disputes her height, claiming not to be a mile high, but the King and Queen correct her, stating she is nearly two miles high.

paragraphs.original: “Well, I shan’t go, at any rate,” said Alice: “besides, that’s not a regular rule: you invented it just now.”  “It’s the oldest rule in the book,” said the King.  “Then it ought to be Number One,” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: Alice refuses to follow the King's rule, arguing it was invented on the spot and shouldn't be considered a valid one, suggesting it should be the first rule if it's truly the oldest.

paragraphs.original: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.  “There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”  “What’s in it?” said the Queen.
paragraphs.summary: The King's face turned pale as he hastily closed his notebook, instructing the jury to consider their verdict in a trembling voice. The White Rabbit interrupted, jumping up in a hurry, to reveal that a new piece of evidence had been discovered, a paper that had just been picked up. The Queen asked to know its contents.

paragraphs.original: “I haven’t opened it yet,” said the White Rabbit, “but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.”  “It must have been that,” said the King, “unless it was written to nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.”  “Who is it directed to?” said one of the jurymen.
paragraphs.summary: The White Rabbit holds a letter written by a prisoner, but hasn't opened it. The King suggests it was written to someone, not to nobody, which is uncommon. A juror asks who the letter is addressed to.

pages.page_summary: Alice is noticed by the jury as they deliberate, and the King interrupts to cite Rule Forty-two, which requires anyone over a mile high to leave the court. Alice disputes her height, but the King and Queen correct her, stating she's nearly two miles high. Alice refuses to leave, arguing the rule is invalid. The King becomes flustered, and the White Rabbit interrupts with a new piece of evidence: a letter written by a prisoner, but its contents are unknown.

paragraphs.original: “It isn’t directed at all,” said the White Rabbit; “in fact, there’s nothing written on the _outside_.” He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added “It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.”  “Are they in the prisoner’s handwriting?” asked another of the jurymen.  “No, they’re not,” said the White Rabbit, “and that’s the queerest thing about it.” (The jury all looked puzzled.)
paragraphs.summary: The White Rabbit reveals that the paper in question is not a letter, but a set of verses, and that it is not written in the prisoner's handwriting, which is a peculiar aspect of the situation.

paragraphs.original: “He must have imitated somebody else’s hand,” said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)  “Please your Majesty,” said the Knave, “I didn’t write it, and they can’t prove I did: there’s no name signed at the end.”  “If you didn’t sign it,” said the King, “that only makes the matter worse. You _must_ have meant some mischief, or else you’d have signed your name like an honest man.”
paragraphs.summary: The King suggests the Knave's handwriting is a forgery, but the Knave denies writing the document, pointing out that there's no signature to prove it's his. The King counters that the lack of a signature makes the situation worse, implying the Knave must have intended to deceive.

paragraphs.original: There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.  “That _proves_ his guilt,” said the Queen.  “It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
paragraphs.summary: The King's clever remark sparks applause, but the Queen misinterprets it as evidence of guilt, while Alice corrects her, pointing out that the Queen lacks understanding of the situation.

paragraphs.original: “Read them,” said the King.  The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. “Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?” he asked.  “Begin at the beginning,” the King said gravely, “and go on till you come to the end: then stop.”
paragraphs.summary: The King instructs the White Rabbit to read, and the Rabbit asks where to start, to which the King responds to begin at the beginning and continue until reaching the end.

paragraphs.original: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:—  “They told me you had been to her,     And mentioned me to him: She gave me a good character,     But said I could not swim.  He sent them word I had not gone     (We know it to be true): If she should push the matter on,     What would become of you?
paragraphs.summary: The White Rabbit reads a poem that mentions him and a woman, who gave him a good character but said he couldn't swim. The poem also states that the White Rabbit had not gone to see her, and warns that if she pushes the matter further, it could harm the speaker.

pages.page_summary: The White Rabbit reveals the paper is a set of verses, not a letter, and not in the prisoner's handwriting. The King suspects the Knave's handwriting is a forgery, but the Knave denies it, pointing out the lack of a signature. The King argues this implies deception, but the Queen misinterprets this as evidence of guilt. The King instructs the White Rabbit to read the poem, which mentions the Rabbit and a woman who gave him a good character but criticized his inability to swim.

paragraphs.original: I gave her one, they gave him two,     You gave us three or more; They all returned from him to you,     Though they were mine before.  If I or she should chance to be     Involved in this affair, He trusts to you to set them free,     Exactly as we were.  My notion was that you had been     (Before she had this fit) An obstacle that came between     Him, and ourselves, and it.
paragraphs.summary: The speaker's child and a friend's child exchanged gifts, but the friend's child took more than their own child gave. The speaker's child and the friend's child are now in a situation where they are being held by the friend, and the speaker is asking the friend to return them to their original state, as if nothing had happened.

paragraphs.original: Don’t let him know she liked them best,     For this must ever be A secret, kept from all the rest,     Between yourself and me.”   “That’s the most important piece of evidence we’ve heard yet,” said the King, rubbing his hands; “so now let the jury—”
paragraphs.summary: The King reveals that a secret between two individuals is crucial evidence, and he interrupts himself to instruct the jury to proceed.

paragraphs.original: “If any one of them can explain it,” said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn’t a bit afraid of interrupting him,) “I’ll give him sixpence. _I_ don’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it.”  The jury all wrote down on their slates, “_She_ doesn’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it,” but none of them attempted to explain the paper.  “If there’s no meaning in it,” said the King, “that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn’t try to find any. And yet I don’t know,” he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; “I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. “—_said I could not swim_—” you can’t swim, can you?” he added, turning to the Knave.
paragraphs.summary: Alice doubts the meaning of a paper, but the jury writes down her statement without attempting to explain it. The King, however, is uncertain, seeing potential meaning in the verses despite initially thinking it was meaningless, and turns to the Knave, asking if he can swim.

paragraphs.original: The Knave shook his head sadly. “Do I look like it?” he said. (Which he certainly did _not_, being made entirely of cardboard.)  “All right, so far,” said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: “‘_We know it to be true_—’ that’s the jury, of course—‘_I gave her one, they gave him two_—’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—”  “But, it goes on ‘_they all returned from him to you_,’” said Alice.
paragraphs.summary: The Knave shook his head, denying the King's implication, despite his cardboard appearance. The King continued to read the verses aloud, interpreting them as evidence of the Knave's guilt, while Alice pointed out a contradictory line that suggested the opposite.

paragraphs.original: “Why, there they are!” said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table. “Nothing can be clearer than _that_. Then again—‘_before she had this fit_—’ you never had fits, my dear, I think?” he said to the Queen.  “Never!” said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)  “Then the words don’t _fit_ you,” said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.
paragraphs.summary: The King points to the tarts on the table, claiming the situation is clear, but the Queen disputes this, recalling that she never had fits before. She throws an inkstand at the Lizard, while the young Bill uses the ink trickling down his face to continue writing on his slate. The King's comment about the Queen's words not fitting her is met with a stunned silence from the court.

pages.page_summary: The speaker's child and a friend's child are in a precarious situation after the friend's child took more than they gave. The speaker asks the friend to restore the situation to its original state. Meanwhile, the King interrupts himself to instruct the jury, revealing that a secret between two individuals is crucial evidence. In the trial, Alice's statement about a paper is written down without explanation, but the King later interprets it as evidence against the Knave. The King's interpretation is disputed by Alice and the Queen, who recall that she never had fits before. The Queen throws an inkstand at the Lizard, while the young Bill continues writing on his slate, and the King's comment about the Queen's words not fitting her is met with stunned silence.

paragraphs.original: “It’s a pun!” the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed, “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.  “No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”  “Stuff and nonsense!” said Alice loudly. “The idea of having the sentence first!”
paragraphs.summary: The King defends his pun, prompting laughter, but the Queen insists that the jury should first consider their verdict, then deliver the sentence, to which Alice objects, deeming the idea absurd.

paragraphs.original: “Hold your tongue!” said the Queen, turning purple.  “I won’t!” said Alice.  “Off with her head!” the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody moved.
paragraphs.summary: The Queen turns purple and orders Alice's head to be cut off, but Alice refuses to be silenced, prompting the Queen to shout the execution order again, still met with inaction.

paragraphs.original: “Who cares for you?” said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”  At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.  “Wake up, Alice dear!” said her sister; “Why, what a long sleep you’ve had!”
paragraphs.summary: Alice, now grown to her full size, insults the pack of cards, prompting them to attack her. She screams and tries to defend herself, but ends up on the bank, where her sister finds her and gently wakes her from a long sleep.

paragraphs.original: “Oh, I’ve had such a curious dream!” said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said, “It _was_ a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it’s getting late.” So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.   But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
paragraphs.summary: Alice shares her vivid dream with her sister, recounting the fantastical events she experienced. Her sister acknowledges the dream's curiosity, but encourages Alice to get ready for tea, dismissing it as just a dream. As Alice departs, her sister remains seated, lost in thought, watching the sunset and reflecting on Alice's adventures, eventually drifting off into a reverie of her own.

paragraphs.original: First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers—she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that _would_ always get into her eyes—and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister’s dream.  The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool—she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution—once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it—once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.  So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality—the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds—the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen’s shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy—and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard—while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle’s heavy sobs.
paragraphs.summary: Alice dreamed of her little sister, and the dream became a vivid recreation of Wonderland, with its fantastical creatures and events. The White Rabbit, March Hare, and Queen of Hearts appeared, along with the pig-baby, Gryphon, and Mock Turtle, creating a chaotic and fantastical atmosphere. As she sat with her eyes closed, Alice half-believed she was still in Wonderland, but knew that reality would return if she opened her eyes, replacing the fantastical sounds with the mundane noises of a farm yard.

pages.page_summary: The King's pun sparks laughter, but the Queen insists on a verdict and sentence, prompting Alice to object. The Queen orders Alice's head cut off, but Alice refuses to be silenced. Alice grows to full size and insults the pack of cards, leading to a chaotic fight. She wakes up on the bank, where her sister finds her and dismisses her vivid dream as just a fantasy. However, Alice's dream was a recreation of Wonderland, complete with fantastical creatures and events, and she half-believed she was still there, but knew reality would return if she opened her eyes.

paragraphs.original: Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make _their_ eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.  THE END
paragraphs.summary: Alice pictures her younger sister growing up, retaining her innocent and loving nature, and one day having children of her own, sharing stories and experiences with them, and cherishing memories of her own childhood.

paragraphs.original: *** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK ALICE'S ADVENTURES IN WONDERLAND ***
paragraphs.summary: The paragraph is not a novel paragraph, but rather a marker indicating the end of the eBook.

pages.page_summary: Alice envisions her younger sister growing up with her innocent and loving nature, eventually having children and passing down cherished memories of her own childhood.

chapters.chapter_summary: Alice's trial in a small English village is in disarray as she denies knowing anything about the situation, despite the King's attempts to question her. The trial is interrupted by various events, including the jury box being knocked over and the introduction of a mysterious letter that may be a forgery. The King and Queen's interpretations of the evidence are disputed, and the trial descends into chaos. Alice eventually grows to full size and insults the pack of cards, leading to a fight, before waking up on the bank with her sister. However, Alice's dream is revealed to be a recreation of Wonderland, complete with fantastical creatures and events, and she is left wondering if reality will return if she opens her eyes.

novel_summary: Alice, feeling bored, falls down a rabbit hole and enters a fantastical world called Wonderland. She encounters various creatures, including a White Rabbit, a Cheshire Cat, and a Duchess, and experiences a series of strange and illogical events. She grows and shrinks in size, attends a chaotic tea party, and participates in a croquet game where the Queen orders beheadings. Along the way, she meets the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon, who share stories about their education and the absurdities of Wonderland. Alice's adventures are marked by her confusion and frustration with the illogical world around her. She is eventually called to testify in a trial, where she denies knowing anything about the situation, and the trial descends into chaos. In the end, Alice wakes up on the bank with her sister, but her dream is revealed to be a recreation of Wonderland, leaving her wondering if reality will return if she opens her eyes.
